title: Mike Phillips offers sympathy to Wales after Rugby World Cup semi-final exit
text:
Retired scrum-half Mike Phillips admits he felt for Wales after they missed out on the Rugby World Cup final with a 19-16 defeat by South Africa.

After Handre Pollard and Dan Biggar had exchanged first-half penalties, a Damian de Allende try was cancelled out by Josh Adams, but Pollard kicked the winning penalty three minutes from time.

Phillips was part of the Wales side that suffered defeat by France in the 2011 Rugby World Cup final, scoring a try in a 9-8 reverse.

Wales endured a painful Rugby World Cup semi-final defeat by South Africa in Japan

Former Wales scrum-half Mike Phillips admitted he had sympathy for the players after the loss

Phillips told ITV: 'It’s so painful, I’ve been there and it still kills me today. It was a poor game to be honest, wasn’t entertaining, lots of kicking.

'Boys right in mix until the end, shame they couldn’t get over the line.'

'They will learn from this experience and move on.'

The @Springboks played poorly to be honest...but ultimately it’s the result that matters. England will be a tough nut to crack... but rather them than the @AllBlacks! #RWC2019 #WALvRSA — Rick Duvenage (@RickDuvenage) October 27, 2019

Some effort considering the strength that we couldn’t put on the pitch. A semi-final is probably a fair reflection of this World Cup. Never quite hit the heights. — George Dugdale (@GeorgeDugdale) October 27, 2019

Bryan Habana added: 'From what was a dour first half to a second half that had more to it. The six forwards who came on made a really impact.

'They’ll take this one on the head, enjoy it tonight, preparation will start early tomorrow.'

Gareth Thomas: 'I think they’ve put everything the line. It was a tough battle, they couldn’t have done anymore.'
description: Retired scrum-half Mike Phillips admits he felt for Wales after they missed out on the Rugby World Cup final with a 19-16 defeat by South Africa.
